events.description:
Richard Trevithick runs the first full-scale working railway steam locomotive.
It demonstrates the potential of steam power for land transport.

Robert Fulton’s Clermont makes a successful steamboat voyage on the Hudson River.
Commercial steam navigation becomes viable.

George Stephenson builds the locomotive Blücher for hauling coal.
It marks a practical step toward modern railways.

Sir Humphry Davy develops the safety lamp for miners.
Accidents in coal mines are reduced by isolating flame from firedamp.

SS Savannah completes the first steam-assisted transatlantic crossing.
Hybrid sail-steam travel proves long-range feasibility.

Michael Faraday demonstrates electromagnetic rotation.
The core principle behind electric motors is revealed.

Charles Babbage proposes the Difference Engine.
A landmark in the conceptual history of computing machinery.

Stockton and Darlington Railway opens in England.
The first public railway to use steam locomotives for passengers and freight.

Nicéphore Niépce creates the first permanent photograph.
A new era of image capture and visual documentation begins.

Michael Faraday discovers electromagnetic induction.
Electric generators and transformers become scientifically grounded.

Samuel Morse demonstrates the electric telegraph.
Long-distance communication accelerates beyond physical mail.

Louis Daguerre announces the daguerreotype process.
Practical photography spreads rapidly across the world.

Ada Lovelace publishes notes on the Analytical Engine.
Her algorithmic insights foreshadow modern programming.

Ether anesthesia is publicly demonstrated in surgery.
Pain management transforms medical practice and outcomes.

Walter Hunt patents the modern safety pin.
A simple, secure fastener becomes a ubiquitous tool.

First submarine telegraph cable is laid across the English Channel.
Subsea communications begin linking nations directly.

The Great Exhibition opens in London’s Crystal Palace.
Industry, design, and innovation are showcased on a global stage.

Henry Bessemer patents the Bessemer steel process.
Mass-produced steel revolutionizes construction and rail.

Charles Darwin publishes On the Origin of Species.
Evolution by natural selection reshapes biology and thought.

The American Civil War begins.
Industrial capacity and logistics become decisive in modern warfare.

A durable transatlantic telegraph cable succeeds.
Near-instant communication connects Europe and North America.

Alfred Nobel patents dynamite.
A safer explosive accelerates mining and infrastructure projects.

Remington introduces a commercially produced typewriter.
Office work and written communication are transformed.

The Metre Convention establishes international standards.
Global metrology coordination improves trade and science.

Alexander Graham Bell patents the telephone.
Voice communication is transmitted electrically over distance.

Thomas Edison demonstrates a practical incandescent bulb.
Electric lighting moves toward widespread adoption.

Edison’s Pearl Street Station begins operation in New York.
One of the first central power plants supplies electric light.

Karl Benz tests a gasoline-powered automobile.
Personal motorized transport takes a decisive step forward.

Nikola Tesla patents the AC induction motor.
Alternating current systems gain a powerful workhorse.

Wilhelm Röntgen discovers X-rays.
Medical diagnostics and physics receive a new probing tool.

J. J. Thomson identifies the electron.
Subatomic physics enters an era of discovery.

Max Planck presents the quantum hypothesis.
Energy quantization challenges classical physics foundations.

The Wright brothers achieve powered, controlled flight.
Aviation begins with sustained flights at Kitty Hawk.

Albert Einstein finalizes general relativity.
Gravity is described as the curvature of spacetime.

Alexander Fleming discovers penicillin.
Antibiotics inaugurate a revolution in medicine.

Alan Turing outlines the concept of computation.
The Turing machine frames limits and power of algorithms.

Chicago Pile-1 achieves the first controlled chain reaction.
Nuclear engineering moves from theory to practice.

The Trinity test and WWII’s end reshape geopolitics.
Nuclear weapons and the UN define a new world order.

The transistor is invented at Bell Labs.
Electronics shrink, paving the path to modern computing.

Alan Turing proposes the Imitation Game.
A seminal test frames debates about machine intelligence.

Sputnik 1 becomes the first artificial satellite.
The Space Age and global space race begin.

Yuri Gagarin orbits Earth as the first human in space.
Crewed spaceflight proves achievable.

Apollo 11 lands humans on the Moon.
Televised steps symbolize technological ambition.

Intel introduces the 4004 microprocessor.
General-purpose computing fits onto a single chip.

The first handheld mobile phone call is made.
Personal, portable telephony takes shape.

IBM launches the IBM PC.
A de facto standard accelerates the personal computing era.

Tim Berners-Lee proposes the World Wide Web.
Hypertext over the internet lays a new information fabric.

Linux is announced by Linus Torvalds.
Open-source operating systems gain a flagship kernel.

Windows 95 popularizes the desktop GUI for consumers.
Mass adoption drives the software and internet boom.

Google is founded by Larry Page and Sergey Brin.
Web search quality leaps, reshaping information access.
